title: Cat.Power.Glastonbury.2013.HDTV.AVC.MP2.50FPS.AVI
description:
This video is the result of me trying to determine how to properly deinterlace a video source which is NOT in MPEG-TS format. 

[NOTE]
Interlaced video streams (all "original" sources are interlaced) in MPEG-TS format are trivially converted to "progressive" Audio Video Interleave (AVI) files without requiring any encoding. This is done using AviDemux (an excellent *freeware* program) which by default, saves both "fields" (called "top" and "bottom") as well as doubling the frame rate, producing a 100% perfect reproduction of the original transport stream for home playback using any media player (for best playback use the LAV decoder).

Unfortunately however, doing the same thing is NOT so easy in the case of a DVD source.
[/NOTE]

In this case, starting with an interlaced DVD (or set of ".VOB" files), AviDemux will open them up, but just saving the data as an AVI file produces an *interlaced* result (meaning: original frame rate, and 2 fields). Since it's still just DVD imagery, the resulting AVI will play fine with any Media Player as well as most DVD players.

However (there's always a catch) you would NOT be able to offer up such files for video streaming websites (like YouTube) because they require you to provide a "progressive-scan" source. This is what's meant by something like "720p"; the "p" here stands for "progressive". 

Analogously there is such a thing called an "720i" video source, where "i" stands for "interlaced". But you will never see a selection for 720i on any website because:

Ã¢â‚¬Â¢ Content delivery from streaming video websites is ALWAYS "progressive".

[NOTE]
Progressive (p) just means that you start with one full image (let's say 1280x720 pixels) and then following that an animation is produced by supplying "changes" (image differences) at regular intervals until the cycle begins again at the next so-called "key frame". That is, a new starting image is sent, followed by a series of "differences" which are "progressively" merged with the first image to create an animation once again, up to the next "key frame" where the next full image is supplied (that's why the YouTube progress bar moves the way it does, and the reason stepping back is slower than forwards).
[/NOTE]

So this here is my result. A progessive 50-FPS scan taken from an interlaced 25-FPS MPEG2 DVD source, which (since I am forced to do a re-encoding anyway) I have converted to use the AVC codec. Playback is smoothest using the LAV decoder. The others ("internal Microsoft" and "libavcodec") aren't nearly as smooth for 50-FPS rendering.
